ygData.subject: Re: [neat] Re: Evolving Neural Turing Machines
ygData.msgSnippet: Hi Ken and Jeff, We are happy you guys enjoyed the paper! We haven t yet tried it on sorting and recall but those are definitely tasks we will try as well. The

From: Sebastian Risi <sebastian.risi@...>

Hi Ken and Jeff,

We are happy you guys enjoyed the paper! We haven't yet t=
ried it on
sorting and recall but those are definitely tasks we will try as=
 well.
The copy task was first on our list because Graves also evaluated
th=
eir SGD-based version on it. We do expect it should work on the
other tasks=
 as well though. It will be interesting to see if evolution
discovers solut=
ions similar to backprop or in what regards they
differ. However, our main =
motivation for the ENTM, and what I find
most excited, was to try it on non=
-supervised tasks (e.g. T-Maze),
which an SGD-based approach can not direct=
ly be applied to.

We actually also have multiple heads implemented but hav=
en't yet
experimented too much with it. Also, Graves et al. used just one r=
ead
and one write head for the copy task and more heads only for priority
s=
ort. Of course, adding more heads will also make the ANN more complex
so an=
 obvious way forward would be to use HyperNEAT instead, which we
have some =
initial
results as well. More on that later :)

Also, Jeff you are correct,=
 Diff-ENTM is not trained with backprop but
instead trained with evolution.=
 We should highlight that more in
subsequent papers.

Please let me know if=
 you have any other questions. We also plan to
make the source code availab=
le soon.

Best,
Sebastian

On Mon, Nov 23, 2015 at 11:17 PM, kstanley@...=
exas.edu [neat]
<neat@yahoogroups.com> wrote:
>
>
>
> Thanks Sebastian, tha=
t was an extremely interesting paper.  It's very impressive that you seem t=
o be doing better than the more complicated SGD-based version.  It's a shor=
t paper though as you know so it leaves all kinds of questions.  I realize =
maybe these are coming in future papers so I'm not sure how much you can an=
swer, but in case you can say more - have you tried it on other tasks from =
the original paper like sorting and recall?  Why did you choose the copying=
 task in particular?  It seems like if you do better on all the tasks that =
should make a lot of impact on the community.  It would also be nice to see=
 the differences between the two approaches more explicitly shown, like in =
a side-by-side graphic or chart of some sort.  Also, why are there the  dif=
ferences that there are?  You make the case that this model is simpler, but=
 was that the main motivation?  For example, the original had multiple head=
s but you have just one - why is that?  It makes me wonder why they didn't =
just try theirs with one, or is there something about SGD that would be und=
ermined if they did that?
>
> Anyway, it raises all kinds of interesting is=
sues and suggests a useful role for evolution in systems where the need to =
differentiate could be a liability, which raises a lot of interesting oppor=
tunities and questions.  Really nice idea.
>
> Best,
>
> ken
>
>
